Section 7(a) of the Small Business Act is amended to include definitions for combination financing, which involves a guaranteed loan and a commercial loan. This applies to small businesses obtaining a loan guarantee and a commercial loan. The commercial loan amount is specified in combination financing. In combination financing, the commercial loan amount cannot exceed the guaranteed loan amount. The commercial loan can be obtained from a different lender, secured by a senior lien, and may be made by a lender in the Preferred Lenders Program. A one-time fee of 0.7 percent of the commercial loan amount is paid to the Administration if the commercial loan has a senior credit position. The loan guaranteed under this subsection may have a deferred participation loan security with a subordinated lien. The Administrator will process applications for combination financing under this program as of October 1, 2003. Small business eligibility standards for combination financing under this subsection will be based on criteria in effect on September 1, 2004. The small business eligibility standards for combination financing under this subsection will be based on criteria in effect on September 1, 2004, and any modifications made by the Administrator after that date should not unreasonably restrict the availability of such financing. SEC. 2. LOAN GUARANTEE FEES. Amendments are made to the Small Business Act regarding annual fees and guarantee fees for loans guaranteed under the Act. The Administrator will assess and collect an annual fee of 0.36 percent of the outstanding balance of the deferred participation share of the loan. Additionally, guarantee fees will be collected for loans repayable in more than 1 year, payable by the participating lender and may be charged to the borrower. The guarantee fees for loans under the Small Business Act are as follows: 1% for loans up to $150,000, 2.5% for loans between $150,000 and $700,000, 3.5% for loans over $700,000, and an additional 0.25% for loans exceeding $1,000,000. SEC. 3. EXPRESS LOAN PROVISIONS. Section 7(a) of the Small Business Act is amended to include definitions for 'express lender,' 'express loan,' and 'Express Loan Program' under the new express loan provisions. The Small Business Act is amended to include definitions for 'express lender,' 'express loan,' and 'Express Loan Program' under new provisions. The authority to make an express loan is limited to qualified lenders designated by the Administrator. Existing express lenders will retain their designation unless violations occur. The Small Business Act defines 'express lender,' 'express loan,' and 'Express Loan Program.' Qualified lenders designated by the Administrator can make express loans up to $2,000,000. The Administrator cannot force lenders to make express loans or change loan terms without their consent. The Administrator cannot limit or modify deferred participation loans under this subsection unless the same limit is imposed on express loans. Transferring staff or resources that would increase loan processing time above 2003 averages is also restricted. The Administrator is prohibited from providing incentives that favor the Express Loan Program over general loan authority. Data collection on loans over $250,000 is required, with reports to Senate and House Small Business Committees. The House Small Business Committee requires reports on the number and purposes of loans over $250,000. SEC. 4. STANDARDS FOR LOANS MADE WITH DEFERRED PARTICIPATION. Standards for loans made with deferred participation under the Small Business Act have specific terms and conditions, including maximum loan amounts and collateral requirements, as of October 1, 2004. The Administrator can take necessary actions to maintain the loan program. The Administrator can maintain the loan program under specific terms and conditions, subject to appropriations. SEC. 5 amends the Small Business Act to increase the guarantee amount to $1.5 million and $1.75 million, with associated fees. SEC. 6 states that these amendments are effective from the date of enactment until September 30, 2005.
